Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 03:12PM emath wrote: I had my SNB on the 23 of July and they took out 5 which a "Frozen Section" was done and it they all came back NEG, so my surgeon did the lumpectomy at that point as well. I had a mammosite put in my breast which drained all the time. They removed it yesterday, which was painful! OUCH!!!! but only after I completed 5 days of Rads twice daily. I am having trouble with raising my left arm and have some numbness from the shoulder to my hand and shooting pains at time from the SNB. That is the only problem I am having. The lumpectomy went fine and really did not hurt. But every woman is different. Some hurt, some don't!
Posts.Title: Drain with SNB? MinAZ emath

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2008 05:22AM emath wrote: Good for you!!!!  I do trust part of my team. The radiation department was great! They made it very personable, like they had known you for years. My surgeon was great and very sweet. It's my oncoligist that I am having a problem with. Today will make the choice of dumping hiim to find another or what. I am not a number or a piece of meat. We all feel this way I am sure. Best of luck to you Mandy. Hope all goes well!
Posts.Title: Cancer, do you trust people? Crisis Mode Jennyany Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2008 09:05AM emath wrote: Thanks Madalyn. I know it is temporary and it will pass. I am this morning looking for another onc. I have been trying to call my onc now for 2 days without any call back. I also have swelling above the incision for the SNB. It came up over night and looks about like someone injected fluid under the skin. It is about the size of a big gumball and tender and hurts. You would think they would call you back. So, I am now looking again! Hearing from others help a great deal. If you don't mind me asking, did you chose chem or what as part of your treatment? I have found out that I will not know my oncotype because nobody ordered done. Is this important to have?
Posts.Title: Cancer, do you trust people? Crisis Mode Jennyany Shirlann

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2008 05:19PM emath wrote: I agree with the others on the oncotype testing. Mine was a 12, and all I did was rads and starting tamox next week. My onc said doing chemo would only drop my percentage 3%, so I opted out for chemo. Now if it had dropped it by 6% I might have considered it. With 0 nodes we are in better shape than others. But the choice is yours alone. Good luck with your choice! ((((((hugs)))))
Posts.Title: need help rayne_23 Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2008 08:32PM emath wrote: You are not alone. We all have waited for test results and had to call for appointments to be told we have cancer. I too did not really hear anything past the word "Cancer". It has been a month since they told me and I still am not sure I have cancer. Like this is a bad nightmare and I can't wake up! I have already had all test possible (not sure if I missed one) had the lumpectomy with SNB. I also had a mammosite inserted in my breast to recieved radiation for 5 day twice a day. This was very uncomfortable, mainly when they took it out (they put a dummy in first) then shove the real ting in (no pain meds involved) Like I like pain. Then after the rads to have it yanked out! OH BOY more pain! To only fiind out that they believe they got it it all, it showed good but slim margins. So, now at Stage 1, tumor 2.0cm, grade 2, T1C and they can't tell me my oncotype yet! Yea, I really don't trust anyone either. I feel this is all a guessing game. When you ask "How do I know it is gone, that you got it all" they answer, "Well we will run an MRI, another mammo (like I need them smashed again right now) and another PET scan in a few weeks. But I need to decide what treatment I want to take. Pills for 5 years, or Pills and Chemo or do nothing. What am I paying these guys for?  We all feel very alone at times, very angry at times, and fustrated. But we keep holding our head high and do what we need to do to get the job done. Hand in there Jenny! I am so sorry that you are having to go through this. But we are al here to help and offer support when we can. ((((((((((((Jenny))))))))))))) hug to you and I will keep you in my prayers. Please come back often and keep us updated on yourself.
Posts.Title: Cancer, do you trust people? Crisis Mode Jennyany Shirlann

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 03:57PM emath wrote: Have you had a biospy yet? I also have no history of any cancer in my family and I am healthy as well. I am 49 and my children are grown, but I do have small grandchildren. I am so sorry you are having to go through this. I will keep you in my prayers. The group here is GREAT and you should come back often. Please keep me informed. May God bless you.
Posts.Title: Scared and waiting... pb1 pb1

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 07:49PM emath wrote: The fear of the unknown can control your life or you can take back control. We can only do so much. Postive think and doing is the best, but we even get tired at times of hearing that. But we are allowed to pout and feel sorry for ourslef. But then we gather our thoughts again and do what we know we need to do. We are women, and we are strong! WE WILL SURVIVE!
Posts.Title: Scared and waiting... pb1 pb1

Posts.Content: Sep 9, 2008 06:46AM emath wrote: I think it effects everyone a little different. I had the core biopsy done with US and wire assisted biopsy with mammogram all done on the same day (both boobs). The shot hurts some, depending on how deep they go. After the shot took effect, all I felt was pressure. They took 8 samples in the right and 6 from the left. Went home with steri strips on both and a big bandage over that. Was told not to get it wet for 3 days. Kept ice packs on both due to the swelling for 4 days. Wore a sports bra for 2 weeks following. Scar, yes a small 1/4 in. on the right and the left was a little bigger but it was taken over by a much bigger scar now due the lumpectomy.
Posts.Title: Core Biopsy w/ U/S, what to expect? CorasMama Jo_Ann_K

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2008 02:01PM emath wrote: I will have a drink when we go out to dinner, but my doctor told me not to anymore. I can't sleep. Feeling very drained. I am not sure what all will happen at this point. But what I do know is that I am scared. It is the fear of the unkown that gets us all. Losing my hair, one breast or even both breast is yet to be seen. Guess I will know more come Wednesday after the appointment with the oncologist. Thank you so much for your response. It does help to talk to others that are going through the same thing. May God bless us all and be with us!
Posts.Title: Ok, so I have cancer emath jdg1

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2008 02:59AM emath wrote: I had my biospy done 3 weeks ago and my lumpectomy on the left breast done 5 days ago. The breast is ok with hardly any pain, but under my arm where they did the nodes I have numbness, cold feelings and pain at times. My surgeon said this is normal and sometimes will last several weeks to months. I have found that I use ice packs over the breast and armpit area and it does help some. It seems to numb that area and the nerves, so I don't notice the other as much. I hope this helps. Hang in there it will get better!
Posts.Title: Will numbness go away??? snoopygirl Jule

Posts.Content: emath wrote: Just hearing the news this past Monday has made me numb. I can't seem to cry about it. I was told that I had Invasive Ductal Carcinoma (low) and Focal Ductal Carcinoma In Situ without necrosis (low-grade). The waiting to find out more is worse than the news itself. Spent 3 hours waiting for my doctor to tell me what I already knew and all she could say is to find an Oncologist. So, I did and I am going next Wednesday. Not sure what the steps are next, but I know that my energy level is getting very low. I have lost some weight and all I want to do is lay around. Is this normal, maybe just from the news I just got? At what point does the initital shock wear off? Ellen Dx 7/7/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage IB, Grade 2, 0/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Ok, so I have cancer emath jdg1

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2008 04:31AM emath wrote: Cheryl, my heart cries for you. I too lost my little doxie of 9 years to cancer 2 months prior to me being dx in July. It broke my heart and I still cry and wished I could hold and love him again. Just know that he is in heaven playing with others. ((((((((((((((((hugs))))))))))))))))
